title: Browser opens new window on every app launch instead of checking for existing tabs
description: After update completes and app restarts normally, every subsequent app launch opens a new browser window/tab instead of detecting existing tabs at http://127.0.0.1:8050. Expected: App should detect if browser tab already exists before launching new one. Actual: webbrowser.open(url, new=2) always opens new tab. Root cause: Python webbrowser module has no API to check for existing tabs. Potential solutions: 1) Add JavaScript-based heartbeat to detect connected clients, 2) Check for active WebSocket connections before launching, 3) Add startup flag --no-browser for manual control, 4) Accept current behavior as limitation of webbrowser module.
notes:
DECISION: AS DESIGNED - NOT A BUG

**User Expectation Analysis**:
When user double-clicks BurndownChart.exe:
- Expected: Browser opens immediately (visual confirmation app started)
- Actual: Browser opens ✅
- This is CORRECT behavior

**Why This Makes Sense**:
1. User has no way to know if app started without browser opening
2. Terminal window might be hidden/minimized
3. System tray icon might not be noticed immediately
4. Opening browser = clear visual feedback that app is running

**Update Scenario is Different**:
- User KNOWS app is running (existing tab open)
- update_reconnect.js handles reconnection automatically
- Flag prevents duplicate tab (correct)

**Multiple Tabs from Repeated Launches**:
- If user launches exe multiple times = multiple tabs is expected
- User controls this by not double-clicking multiple times
- System tray 'Open in Browser' available if tab is closed

**Conclusion**: Current behavior is correct by design. Closing as not a bug.

notes:
DECISION: KEEP update_reconnect.js

EVALUATION SUMMARY:
✅ Implementation is clean and reliable
✅ All integration tests pass (4/4)
✅ Complexity is manageable (3 files, ~75 LOC total)
✅ UX benefit is significant (single tab vs 2 tabs after update)
✅ Edge cases handled gracefully (missing DB, concurrent access)

IMPLEMENTATION DETAILS:
- updater/updater.py: 41 lines (flag write + error handling)
- app.py: 29 lines (flag read + cleanup)
- tests/integration/test_update_workflow.py: 200 lines (4 comprehensive tests)

KEY STRENGTHS:
1. Uses existing database infrastructure (no new dependencies)
2. Atomic operations with SQLite (no race conditions)
3. Graceful degradation (falls back to normal launch if flag fails)
4. One-time flag (auto-cleanup prevents state pollution)
5. System tray 'Open in Browser' still works (flag only affects auto-launch)

EDGE CASES COVERED:
- Missing database file → app launches normally
- Concurrent flag access → SQLite locking handles it
- Flag cleanup failure → next launch clears it anyway
- Updater crash before flag write → app launches normally

RECOMMENDATION: Feature complete and production-ready. Close xmc and deploy.

title: Design self-updating updater architecture
description:
Based on research findings, design a solution for updating both BurndownChart.exe and BurndownChartUpdater.exe.

Requirements:
- Both executables must be updated atomically
- Handle Windows file locking (cannot replace running executable)
- Prevent corruption if update interrupted
- Backward compatible with existing update flow
- Clear rollback strategy on failure

Consider approaches:
1. Two-phase update (app updates updater first, then updater updates app)
2. Temporary updater copy that updates both files
3. App-managed updater replacement before launching updater
4. Delayed file operations (MoveFileEx with MOVEFILE_DELAY_UNTIL_REBOOT)

Deliverable: Design document in specs/self-updating-updater/design.md with:
- Architecture diagrams
- Update flow sequence
- Error handling strategy
- File operation order
- Rollback mechanism

Code location: app.py startup sequence, after logging initialization, before server start.

title: Implement download state persistence to database
description: Persist update download state to app_state table. Store: pending_update_version, pending_update_path, pending_update_url. Restore on startup if file exists. Clear after successful update. Implement in update_manager.py and app.py.
notes:
Implementation details:

Problem: Download state lost on app restart. User downloads ~100MB ZIP → app crashes → Windows cleans %TEMP% → state lost. Current: app.VERSION_CHECK_RESULT is in-memory only.

Database keys (app_state table):
- pending_update_version (str): e.g., '1.2.3'
- pending_update_path (str): e.g., 'C:\Users\...\AppData\Local\Temp\burndown_updates\BurndownChart-1.2.3.zip'
- pending_update_url (str): Download URL for re-download fallback
- pending_update_size (int): File size in bytes (for progress bar)
- pending_update_checked_at (str): ISO timestamp (for staleness check, >7 days → re-check)

Code changes:
1. data/update_manager.py: Save to database on download complete via backend.set_app_state()
2. app.py: Restore on startup, verify file exists, populate app.VERSION_CHECK_RESULT
3. Clear after successful update (atexit handler or updater flag)

Fallback: If file missing → set status AVAILABLE (re-download required, no crashes)

title: Add fallback logic for missing temp files
description: Implement graceful degradation when pending_update_path file deleted from %TEMP%. Check file existence on startup, fall back to AVAILABLE state if missing. No crashes or error dialogs, just require re-download.

title: Add fallback logic for missing temp files
description: Implement graceful degradation when pending_update_path file deleted from %TEMP%. Check file existence on startup, fall back to AVAILABLE state if missing. No crashes or error dialogs, just require re-download.
notes:
Implementation details:

Problem: Windows Disk Cleanup or user manually deletes files from %TEMP%, breaking update state.

Solution: Graceful degradation with file existence checks.

Code location: app.py startup, in restore_pending_update() function.

Logic:
- Restore pending_update_path from database
- Check if Path(path_str).exists()
- If exists: Set VERSION_CHECK_RESULT status='READY' (downloaded, ready to install)
- If missing: Set VERSION_CHECK_RESULT status='AVAILABLE' (need to re-download)
- Clear stale database keys: backend.set_app_state('pending_update_path', None)
- Log warning but no error dialogs

Behavior matches industry standard (Chrome, Firefox): Missing download → fall back to 'download again' state.

Testing: Delete ZIP from %TEMP% → restart app → verify UI shows download button (not install button)

title: Add system tray icon for background app control
description:
Implement system tray icon for console-free executable to provide user control and visibility.

REQUIREMENTS:

1. System Tray Icon:
   - Appears in Windows system tray when app runs
   - Uses app icon (assets/icon.ico)
   - Shows on hover: 'Burndown Chart - Running on http://127.0.0.1:8050'

2. Context Menu Actions:
   - 'Open in Browser' - Opens/focuses http://127.0.0.1:8050 in default browser
   - 'Quit' - Gracefully shuts down app (sys.exit(0))

3. Implementation Details:
   - Library: pystray (https://pypi.org/project/pystray/)
   - Add to requirements.in: pystray>=0.19.5
   - Tray icon runs in separate daemon thread
   - Must not block Dash/Waitress server
   - Icon file: assets/icon.ico (already exists for executable)

4. Files to Modify:
   - requirements.in - add pystray dependency
   - app.py - initialize tray icon when running as frozen executable
   - build/app.spec - ensure icon.ico is bundled (already is)

5. Code Structure:
   `python
   if getattr(sys, 'frozen', False):  # Only for executable
       import pystray
       from PIL import Image
       
       def on_open(icon, item):
           webbrowser.open('http://127.0.0.1:8050')
       
       def on_quit(icon, item):
           icon.stop()
           sys.exit(0)
       
       icon = pystray.Icon('burndown-chart',
           Image.open('assets/icon.ico'),
           'Burndown Chart',
           menu=pystray.Menu(
               pystray.MenuItem('Open in Browser', on_open),
               pystray.MenuItem('Quit', on_quit)
           ))
       
       # Run in separate thread
       threading.Thread(target=icon.run, daemon=True).start()
   `

6. Testing Checklist:
   - [ ] Tray icon appears when app starts
   - [ ] Hover shows app name and URL
   - [ ] 'Open in Browser' launches/focuses browser tab
   - [ ] 'Quit' cleanly shuts down app
   - [ ] Icon disappears when app exits
   - [ ] No tray icon when running 'python app.py' (source mode)
   - [ ] Works with update flow (old icon stops, new icon appears)

BENEFITS:
- User can always reopen browser if tab closed
- Clean way to quit without Task Manager
- Visibility that app is running
- Professional UX like mailhog, Docker Desktop, etc.

DEPENDENCIES:
- pystray: System tray icon library
- PIL/Pillow: Image handling (already installed via other deps)

BLOCKED BY:
- burndown-chart-rk4 (update UX improvements must be tested first)

title: Update mechanism UX improvements: speed, cleanup, silent operation
description:
Comprehensive improvements to the update flow beyond initial implementation:

COMPLETED IMPROVEMENTS:

1. App Exit Fix (CRITICAL):
   - Changed from graceful shutdown (blocking) to os._exit(0)
   - Allows updater to immediately replace executable files
   - File: data/update_manager.py

2. Speed Optimizations:
   - Added psutil for faster process detection (0.1s vs 0.5s polling)
   - Reduced updater delays: 1s → 0s after process exit, 3s → 1s final window
   - Faster tasklist polling fallback (0.2s vs 0.5s)
   - Total improvement: ~2-3 seconds faster update
   - Files: updater/updater.py, requirements.in

3. Cleanup Improvements:
   - Remove .bak file after successful update
   - Remove update ZIP file
   - Clean up temp directories (burndown_updater, burndown_updates)
   - File: updater/updater.py

4. Background Download with Progress:
   - Download runs in background thread (non-blocking UI)
   - Live progress bar updates via polling (0% → 100%)
   - Completion toast when download finishes
   - Files: callbacks/app_update.py, ui/layout.py

5. Footer Fallback Button:
   - Footer button works at all update stages
   - Triggers download when AVAILABLE, install when READY
   - Prevents need to restart app if toast dismissed
   - Files: callbacks/app_update.py, ui/layout.py

6. Silent Operation (Console-Free):
   - Changed app.spec: console=True → console=False
   - Changed updater.spec: console=True → console=False
   - No terminal windows at any stage
   - Clean background service like mailhog
   - All logs still in logs/app.log and logs/errors.log
   - Files: build/app.spec, build/updater.spec

7. User Guidance:
   - Toast message tells user to close browser tab
   - Clear instructions that new tab will open automatically
   - 30-second toast duration covers entire update process
   - File: callbacks/app_update.py

8. Browser Handling:
   - Changed webbrowser.open() to open(url, new=2, autoraise=True)
   - Attempts to reuse window (browser-dependent)
   - Auto-launches browser when no browser open
   - File: app.py

FILES MODIFIED:
- data/update_manager.py (exit fix)

title: Add changelog to GitHub Release notes during version bump

title: Review and improve about dialog tab structure
description: Evaluate whether having latest release in App Info tab AND full changelog in separate tab is redundant. Research common practices for about dialogs. Consider: (1) Keep current structure, (2) Remove duplication - only show version info in App Info, (3) Merge into single scrollable view. Decide on best UX and implement.
notes: Current structure: App Info (version + latest 5 items), Open Source (core tech attributions), Licenses (full list), Changelog (full history). Research shows this is GOOD UX practice - 'What's New' preview in App Info with link to full changelog is common (VS Code, Slack, GitHub Desktop do this). Users want quick info without scrolling. DECISION: Keep current structure - it follows best practices and provides good progressive disclosure.
